comments.body: Out of curiosity, where did the letter spacing come from?
Good point. Adding comments in code about their provenance.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +35,39 @@  fontFamily: '.SF Pro Text',
  fontSize: 17.0,
  letterSpacing: -0.38,
  color: CupertinoColors.black,
  decoration: TextDecoration.none,

comments.body: A thought on all of these constants we have throughout cupertino files...I'm thinking that maybe we should aggregate all such constants in a single cupertino file so that other developers can use them, if desired.  I'm sure developers will need to create their own iOS styled widgets and it would be nice if they had a way to ensure they're using the same colors, border radii, etc. that we use.

I agree. Common ones should be in cupertino/colors.dart. Though iOS doesn't really semantically catalog them in a public place so I hesitate to put new ones in there each time I encounter a new color since namespace real estate is valuable. I generally comb the code each time I see a color and if I can figure out a pattern, I add it to CupertinoColors. For the ones that are seemingly domain specific like these ones as far as I can tell for now, I leave them private in their place of use.
Can you describe what a "text field overlay" is?
Adding more text in a next paragraph

I think a couple of code snippets here would probably be much more clear than a description of what to do.  You can show a code snippet for setting an initial value, and a code snippet for selecting text.
Good point. Adding
Do we want people to be able to control this?  Does a UITextField ever not have the decoration in normal iOS development?
Yes, the iOS text fields are fairly customizable

I think there's a connection here with decoration.  I think we either need to impose iOS styling for both the hint text and the decoration, or not enforce styling for either.  If we want to allow a custom decoration, then we should also allow a custom text style for the hint text.

I know we've talked a bit about this before, but I would again consider an enforcement of iOS styling with widgets that are meant to replicate iOS widgets.  We can provide the constituent pieces if people want to assemble their own iOS-ish widgets, but I'm still concerned that people can instantiate specific iOS widgets that then look nothing like the actual iOS widgets....

This is to the iOS convention. iOS allows fairly flexible decoration around the box and control of the font. But the single font knob controls both the text entry and the placeholder text. Thus strings only for both the TextEditingController's text and the placeholder argument.
nit: blank line between an enum value and the next's dartdoc
Thanks for review. Done
sample code should be in a `## Sample code` section so it gets analyzed.
done

nits: `else` should be on the same line as the `}`.
If one block has `{}`, all should.
pasta copy
assert that attachment is non-null before the switch, then you can remove this assert.
not sure if I understood correctly. This is just to make sure adding new enum values in the future fails visibly
`return _lastTapOffset != null`
I'm not just returning there. It does more stuff after the if :)
Sorry about that. I blame code review tunnel vision.

Maybe at some point in the future we should factor this into a reusable something (like a gesture recognizer) that just handled tap up and down and cancel events and mapped them to a double tap (or multitap) callback.

Perhaps, but having a single long recognizer instead of multiple small discreet recognizers means that one recognizer needs to have hooks to call back all tap/long tap/force tap/drag combinations etc since none of them are second class citizen enough to not be included in a recognizer that just takes in taps up/down. 

Leaving it scenario specific for now until we see other scenarios using something of this complexity.
Definitely. Didn't mean to imply that anything needed to be done now.
